thread.title: MLB Power Rankings
thread.title_full: MLB Power Rankings - Sports - The Buffalo News

author: buffalonews
title: MLB Power Rankings
text:
(Through Friday night’s games, last week in parentheses)
1. St. Louis Cardinals. First team to 100 wins since '11 Phillies makes them World Series favorite. (1)
2. Pittsburgh Pirates. Hoping Arrieta doesn’t ace them in NL wild-card game like Bumgarner did last year.
3. Chicago Cubs. Maddon said he doesn’t believe in curses. We’ll see. (3)
4. Toronto Blue Jays. After two celebrations 22 years in the making, it’s time to get down to the real business. (5)
5. Kansas City Royals. Went just 11-17 in September in slow trot to finish. (4)
6. Los Angeles Dodgers. Kershaw needs to get it done in postseason this time. (6)
7. New York Mets. Good for Harvey to finally take a stand and demand the ball. (7)
8. Texas Rangers. Have been as hot as the Blue Jays but nobody has noticed. (9)
9. New York Yankees. Pitching remains a huge question mark. (8)
10. Houston Astros. No matter the result, they were far ahead of their timeline. (10)
11. Los Angeles Angels. Tremendous push to the end for wild-card. (12)
12. Minnesota Twins. Molitor has done great job in rookie year as skipper. (13)
13. San Francisco Giants. The odd-number year jinx strikes again. (11)
14. Washington Nationals. Papelbon-Harper dugout brawl a low moment in lost season. (14)
15. Cleveland Indians. This year’s Exhibit A of why losing in April is just as costly as any other month. (16).
16. Arizona Diamondbacks. Pushed right to the end to get to .500. (19)
17. Baltimore Orioles. Tug of war brewing between Buck and GM Duquette. (15)
18. Boston Red Sox. Someone hire him: Buffalo BBHOFer Lovullo entered weekend 28-17 as interim skipper. (20)
19. Tampa Bay Rays. Three-game attendance total at the Trop for series vs. Marlins was just 28,238. Pathetic. (18)
20. Seattle Mariners. End has to be near for McClendon as manager. (17)
21. Chicago White Sox. Chic preseason pick did nothing all season. (21)
22. San Diego Padres. With ex-Red Sox exec Dee as president, how about California native Lovullo for this spot? (22)
23. Detroit Tigers. Run of four straight Central titles ends with first losing season since ’08. (23)
24. Miami Marlins. Going to have to move into start-over mode again. (24)
25. Milwaukee Brewers. Slipped into irrelevant portion of NL Central. (26)
26. Oakland Athletics. Season ruined by MLB-worst 19-34 mark in one-run games. (25)
27. Colorado Rockies. What must Reyes be thinking watching Blue Jays now? (28).
28. Atlanta Braves. Cleaned house with hopes of contending in new park in ‘17. (29)
29. Cincinnati Reds. Horrific losing streak marks first last-place finish since ’83. (27)
30. Philadelphia Phillies. Just 26-55 on road en route to worst season since 1969. (30)
